CVS chief medical officer: 'We are not looking to build the entire healthcare delivery ecosystem'`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/cvs-chief-medical-officer-we-are-not-looking-to-build-the-entire-healthcare-delivery-ecosystem-164059258.html`2024-02-10 16:40:59`"The role of retail players in healthcare
column4: is being closely watched by investors and clinicians alike.In its latest earnings
column5: CVS emphasized a continued strategy in health services
column6: even as competitor Walgreens (WBA) has signaled a pullback. Through its recent acquisitions of home health provider Signify
column7: and primary care provider for seniors Oak Street
column8: CVS is continuing to look for ways to create a closed loop for patients within its own system.""Oak Street ended the year with 202
column9: 000 at risk lives an increase of 27% versus the prior year. Through January
column10: the number of Aetna members enrolled in Oak Street Clinic has doubled
column11: said CEO Karen Lynch on the recent earnings call.""Signify completed 649
column13: an increase of 20% versus the same period last year. Among our Aetna customers
column14: we are broadening our addressable market utilizing Signify's strong capabilities in other products
column16: Lynch said.Chief medical officer Sree Chaguturu told Yahoo Finance the company is ""building a world of health around every consumer.""""We are not looking to build the entire health care delivery ecosystem. But where we are choosing to build is where we believe there's the greatest opportunity to improve health outcomes. That's primary care
column18: home services and physician enablement and accountable care — and that's helping physicians participate in value-based care
column20: wide-ranging interview.When asked if those services step on the toes of legacy providers
column21: like hospital systems and physician groups
column22: by taking market share away from less complex cases
column23: Chaguturu said it was the opposite.""These are the most complex patients in our healthcare ecosystem
column25: and in addition to the chronic illnesses
column26: many aspects of social fragility and social determinants of need
column27: he said.The company's recent earnings beat Wall Street expectations
column29: compared to an expected $90.7 billion. But it cut its 2024 outlook
column30: expecting an expensive year ahead.That includes increased utilization costs for Aetna Medicare Advantage patients as delayed services from the pandemic continue to come back
column33: becoming a target for lawmakers in Congress who are looking at ways to reduce the power of such ""middlemen."" Typically
column34: such middlemen are blamed for increased costs in the health ecosystem
column35: but Chaguturu says they will help in the rush of use of weight loss drugs.The frenzy over GLP-1s
column36: drugs that have been used for diabetics to help increase insulin production and help slow digestion
column37: have been approved in the past few years for weight loss in obese patients.Though GLP-1s
column38: named for the hormone in the body they mimic
column40: the latest formulations have had record weight loss results. That has spurred a rush of interest ranging from patients to online health platforms looking to take advantage of the trend by offering prescriptions.Still
column42: 80% of the prescriptions for the four top-selling drugs
column43: from Novo Nordisk (NVO) and Eli Lilly (LLY)
column44: are for Type 2 diabetes patients.Chaguturu said the PBMs will continue to drive down pricing to ensure access for more patients
column45: and expects that more competition — which could begin as early as the end of this year — will also help drive down costs. CVS benefits by earning fees on the prescriptions of the drug it fills
column46: as well as the rebates it gains from the drug manufacturers for covering the drugs and providing access to patients.But it isn't an unfettered gold rush. CVS is working with hesitant customers
column48: who worry about the increased costs. The roughly $1
column49: 000-per-month GLP-1 drugs have caused some employers and insurers to stop covering them
column50: or to require prior authorization in order to fill the prescription.That includes CVS's own insurer
column52: which told Yahoo Finance previously that
column53: ""Prior authorization is required for coverage of these medications. This process allows our clinicians to review the request using evidence-based guidelines to ensure that coverage is appropriate given the member’s clinical status. The prior authorization process may include a review of the member’s age
column55: previous medical history and response to previous therapy.""CVS is also building clinical support for the employers and insurers
column56: to ensure patients who get prescriptions actually need them
column57: and then providing support to manage any side effects
column58: according to Chaguturu.He said clients are taking a variety of approaches to GLP-1s
column59: including waiting until prices come down
column60: or until a way to ensure appropriate prescribing is in place
column61: before agreeing to cover them.""In addition to bringing down pricing
column62: we offer coverage and clinical solutions to help employers and health plans have access
column63: he said.He expects new competitors on the scene
column64: driving the ability to bring down pricing per prescription and net cost of prescription over the coming years.Anjalee Khemlani is the senior health reporter at Yahoo Finance
column70: and health policy and politics. Follow Anjalee on all social media platforms @AnjKhem.Click here for in-depth analysis of the latest health industry news and events impacting stock pricesRead the latest financial and business news from Yahoo FinanceRelated Quotes"`['AMZN'

column2: according to a company filing on Friday
column3: soon after laying out a plan to sell his shares over the next year.The sale took place on Wednesday and Thursday
column5: Amazon said that Bezos would sell up to 50 million shares in the firm.The sale plan
column6: which is subject to certain conditions
column9: and would be completed by Jan. 31
column11: according to the company's latest annual report.Bezos
column12: who stepped down as the company's chief executive and took over as executive chairman in 2021
column13: founded Amazon as a bookseller in 1994.He is currently the world's second richest person with a net worth of $200 billion
column14: according to Bloomberg Billionaires Index.(Reporting by Baranjot Kaur in Bengaluru; editing by Diane Craft)Related Quotes`['AMZN']`

column3: then you can take a look at the Top 5 Stocks To Buy In 10 Different Sectors for the Next 3 Months.The spread of technology and the broad use of the Internet by people belonging to all walks of life has significantly increased the exposure that people have to information. This is true for politics
column5: and finance - as both those who work in these industries and others whose well being is tied to their performance are able to stay abreast with the latest developments. Social media stocks such as Meta Platforms

Do Its Financials Have Any Role To Play In Driving Amazon.com
column2: Inc.'s (NASDAQ:AMZN) Stock Up Recently?`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/financials-role-play-driving-amazon-120024420.html`2024-02-10 12:00:24`"Amazon.com (NASDAQ:AMZN) has had a great run on the share market with its stock up by a significant 22% over the last three months. We wonder if and what role the company's financials play in that price change as a company's long-term fundamentals usually dictate market outcomes. In this article
column3: we decided to focus on Amazon.com's  ROE.Return on equity or ROE is an important factor to be considered by a shareholder because it tells them how effectively their capital is being reinvested. Put another way
column4: it reveals the company's success at turning shareholder investments into profits. See our latest analysis for Amazon.com The formula for ROE is:Return on Equity = Net Profit (from continuing operations) ÷ Shareholders' EquitySo
column6: the ROE for Amazon.com is:15% = US$30b ÷ US$202b (Based on the trailing twelve months to December 2023).The 'return' is the income the business earned over the last year. Another way to think of that is that for every $1 worth of equity
column7: the company was able to earn $0.15 in profit.We have already established that ROE serves as an efficient profit-generating gauge for a company's future earnings. Depending on how much of these profits the company reinvests or ""retains""
column8: and how effectively it does so
column9: we are then able to assess a company’s earnings growth potential. Assuming everything else remains unchanged
column10: the higher the ROE and profit retention
column11: the higher the growth rate of a company compared to companies that don't necessarily bear these characteristics.To begin with
column12: Amazon.com seems to have a respectable ROE. Yet
column13: the fact that the company's ROE is lower than the industry average of 19% does temper our expectations. However
column14: the moderate 5.7% net income growth seen by Amazon.com over the past five years is definitely a positive. So
column15: there might be other aspects that are positively influencing earnings growth. Such as - high earnings retention or an efficient management in place. However
column17: the company does have a decent ROE to begin with
column18: just that it is lower than the industry average. So this also does lend some color to the fairly high earnings growth seen by the company.As a next step
column19: we compared Amazon.com's net income growth with the industry and were disappointed to see that the company's growth is lower than the industry average growth of 13% in the same period.Earnings growth is a huge factor in stock valuation. It’s important for an investor to know whether the market has priced in the company's expected earnings growth (or decline). This then helps them determine if the stock is placed for a bright or bleak future. What is AMZN worth today? The  intrinsic value infographic in our free research report  helps visualize whether AMZN is currently mispriced by the market.Amazon.com doesn't pay any dividend
column20: meaning that all of its profits are being reinvested in the business
column21: which explains the fair bit of earnings growth the company has seen.Overall
column22: we feel that Amazon.com certainly does have some positive factors to consider. Specifically
column23: we like that the company is reinvesting a huge chunk of its profits at a respectable rate of return. This of course has caused the company to see a good amount of growth in its earnings. With that said
column24: the latest industry analyst forecasts reveal that the company's earnings are expected to accelerate. To know more about the latest analysts predictions for the company
column25: check out this visualization of analyst forecasts for the company.Have feedback on this article? Concerned about the content? Get in touch with us directly. Alternatively
column26: email editorial-team (at) simplywallst.com.This article by Simply Wall St is general in nature. We provide commentary based on historical data and analyst forecasts only using an unbiased methodology and our articles are not intended to be financial advice. It does not constitute a recommendation to buy or sell any stock
column27: and does not take account of your objectives
column28: or your financial situation. We aim to bring you long-term focused analysis driven by fundamental data. Note that our analysis may not factor in the latest price-sensitive company announcements or qualitative material. Simply Wall St has no position in any stocks mentioned.Related Quotes"`['AMZN']`
